com.analog.lyric.dimple.factorfunctions.core

Interface IParametricFactorFunction

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IFactorFunction
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Bernoulli, Beta, Categorical, Dirichlet, Gamma, InverseGamma, LogNormal, Normal, Poisson, Rayleigh, VonMises

    public interface IParametricFactorFunction
extends IFactorFunction
    Parametric factor function supporting generic parameter lookup.

    Non-abstract factor functions that implement this interface are expected to provide a constructor that takes a single argument of type Map<String,Object> that specifies the function's initial parameter values.

    Since:
    0.07

    • Method Detail

      • copyParametersInto

        int copyParametersInto(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> parameters)
        Copies the current parameter values in provided parameters map.

        This will do nothing if hasConstantParameters() is false.

        Parameters:
        parameters - is a map into which the entries will be written. Existing entries may be overwritten if they match an added parameter name, but will otherwise be left alone.
        Returns:
        the number of entries that were added to the map.
        Since:
        0.07

      • getParameter

        @Nullable
java.lang.Object getParameter(java.lang.String parameterName)
        Returns the value of the specified parameter.

        Parameters:
        parameterName - identifies the parameter. Some factors may provide more than one way to retrieve a parameter.
        Returns:
        the parameter value or null if there is no such parameter with the given parameterName or if hasConstantParameters() is false.
        Since:
        0.07

      • hasConstantParameters

        boolean hasConstantParameters()
        Indicates that the function's parameters are stored as constants within the factor function itself.

        If false, then the parameters will instead need to be provided as variables attached to the factor. See the documentation for the specific function for details as to how the variables should be ordered, but most often parameter variables come first.

        Not that when true the parameter is only "constant" in the sense that it is not represented as a variable in the graph. Some factor functions may still allow the value of the parameter to be changed after construction.

        Since:
        0.07
